text: As someone from Europe, I can assure you there's always time for meetings during your morning aka their evening. Scheduling also does the trick

text: Freelancers, what kind of onboarding do you like to have with new clients? Product walkthroughs? Several meetings? Have you ever had a client onboard multiple freelancers at the same time? Thanks!

text:
I had a "how we do SEO" with another freelancer when I started writing for RingCentral. I guess it was great for them as they didn't have to do it twice.

Though it was pretty one way so could have even been a video.

text:
I think what I do want depends on the type of engagement. Am I a freelance writer with a one-off gig? In that case, just send me the brief :upside_down_face:

If you want me to start a content strategy from scratch and we've signed a year retainer, intro me to product owners, show me the demos you show your customers then give me access to the product.

In any scenario, please please arm me with product descriptions, CTAs, contacts to reach out to for comment, case studies, the works.

elements.text: I think what I do want depends on the type of engagement. Am I a freelance writer with a one-off gig? In that case, just send me the brief

If you want me to start a content strategy from scratch and we've signed a year retainer, intro me to product owners, show me the demos you show your customers then give me access to the product.

In any scenario, please please arm me with product descriptions, CTAs, contacts to reach out to for comment, case studies, the works.

text:
I've had several onboarding with different clients since 2019:
First one was a month long onboarding with videos, calls with other people on the team, product walk through (document & video) and lots of documentation. Tbf, they were in a highly technical industry.

Second was a few video calls and links to needed documentation (including product walk through videos and documents) on their website.

Third was just 3 documents on brand voice and tone, there was no product walkthrough. Our relationship ended very quickly because I didn't feel supported to produce my best work.

Recent two onboarding have been like onboarding number 2.

If it's a SaaS product, a product walk through (video & document) is a must. Another thing to include in onboarding documentation is your customers and where they stand on the technical scale if you're in a technical industry.

Hope this helps.
PS: Sorry for the wall of text.

If it's a SaaS product, a product walk through (video & document) is a must. Another thing to include in onboarding documentation is your customers and where they stand on the technical scale if you're in a technical industry.

Hope this helps.

text:
hey all! I have a lead on some potential ongoing content work (blogs, case studies, potentially whitepapers) for a HR tech startup called HiPeople, based in Berlin. I've worked with them before and they're really nice folks.

I had a quick chat with their Content Lead today, and she's really looking for folks with a strong background in HR writing/HR tech. I don't have info on their budget, but I said I'd put some feelers out. DM me if you're interested! :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I came across the Superpath salary report in another channel: <https://superpath.co/blog/content-marketing-salary-report> I'm curious to know more about what the freelance content marketers here are doing to find clients and steady work. How do you market yourself? Do you offer very specific services, or a range? Do you focus on a specific client base, or do you work with any kind of client? Do you find work through your connections, or through organic site traffic, or your social media presence, etc.? Thanks!

attachments.fallback: Your Content Career Headquarters: How Much Money Do Content Marketer's Make? (2022 Salary Report) — Your Content Career Headquarters
attachments.text: The average content marketing salary is $93,725. Check out our salary report for more detailed data on job titles, experience and pay discrepancies.

text: I am going back to full-time freelancing after a few years in-house. I try my best to keep my content within the HR tech space although I occasionally take on other work if I am working with a client I love. I find some clients who reach out organically through my freelance site, I have some clients on Upwork, and I have used sites like LinkedIn and this Slack group to find some clients. It's important to me that I use a variety of places to find clients I love to work with.
